benchmark_details.name: Beyond Western Politics: Cross-Cultural Benchmarks for Evaluating Partisan Associations in LLMs
benchmark_details.overview: The paper introduces two datasets, NeutQA-440 (non-adversarial prompts) and AdverQA-440 (adversarial prompts), designed to evaluate political biases in large language models (LLMs) through comparative plausibility judgments involving political leaders and parties in the USA and India.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To audit harmful partisan associations in LLMs through comparative plausibility judgments, with an aim to integrate partisan bias testing into standard LLM benchmarks.

data.source: Datasets created by the authors measuring partisan biases in LLMs.
data.annotation: Designed by the authors through carefully constructed prompts.

methodology.calculation: The models' performances were analyzed using a three-step evaluation pipeline focusing on bias detection, directional consistency, and aggregate asymmetry.
methodology.interpretation: Higher susceptibility indicates significant partisan bias in LLMs based on provided datasets.
methodology.baseline_results: Bias rates exceeding 91% across all models tested.
methodology.validation: Systematic findings across multiple LLMs provide validation.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The dataset covers political leaders and parties from the USA and India, ensuring a comparative context.
targeted_risks.harm: Potential amplification of political division and unintentional reinforcement of biases.
